name: Neo-Y evolution with male recombination
description: Drosophila albomicans has a pair of young neo-sex chromosomes. Surprisingly, the males of this species used to recombine. We explore the effects recombination has had on the neo-Y chromsome.

name: Assembling the massive neo-Y of D. miranda
description:
Drosophila miranda has a neo-Y chromosome that is ~1 million years old. Because it is heavily degenerate with pseudogenes and repetitive elements, we used multiple state-of-the-art genome assembly technologies to piece it together. This includes Pac-Bio, BAC clone, and BioNano sequencing and scaffolding with chromosome contact data (Hi-C). The resulting neo-Y chromosome is in two contigs, and is three times the size of the ancestral autosome from which it derived.
Mahajan, Shivani, Kevin H-C Wei, Matthew J. Nalley, Lauren Gibilisco, and Doris Bachtrog. 2018. “De Novo Assembly of a Young Drosophila Y Chromosome Using Single-Molecule Sequencing and Chromatin Conformation Capture.” PLoS Biology 16 (7): e2006348.

name: Evolution of simple satellites in Drosophila
description:
We profiled the simple satellite landscape across 9 Drosophila species. We found a surprising large amount of diversity driven predominantly by the gains of lineage-specific satellites. Interestingly, newly emerged satellites are also closely related in sequence to existing satellites
Wei, Kevin H-C, Sarah E. Lower, Ian V. Caldas, Trevor J. S. Sless, Daniel A. Barbash, and Andrew G. Clark. 2018. “Variable Rates of Simple Satellite Gains across the Drosophila Phylogeny.” Molecular Biology and Evolution 35 (4): 925–41.

name: Detecting meiotic drive with pooled sequencing
description: We developed a new approach that integrates classical genetics with genomics to identify non-Mendelian transmission frequency. Using this approach we identified a weak centromeric driver.
